title: WAGs in Baden Baden remembered amid Coleen Rooney Rebekah Vardy feud
text:
It’s kicking off (Picture: Getty/Rex)

Coleen Rooney and Rebekah Vardy’s feud has taken over social media – so much so that their row even made it into the New York Times.

It’s like a real life version of Footballers’ Wives – Coleen, 33, shared a statement revealing that she had been plotting for months to expose somebody she suspected was watching her private Instagram stories and selling the stories to the press. The statement ended with the literary genius: ‘It’s………. Rebekah Vardy’s account.’

Rebekah, 37, immediately denied the allegations and has went on to confirm she is getting a ‘forensic investigation’ on her Instagram account to prove she’s not the culprit.

Former WAG Danielle Lloyd then got involved, saying she’s had ‘similar run-ins’ with Becky.

It’s the dream scandal.

The WAGs dominated 2006 (Picture: DPA/PA Images)

England’s footballers were permitted to bring their partners to Germany (Picture: REUTERS/Dylan Martinez)

Carly Zucker, Alex Curran and Lisa Roughead were among the squad (Picture: Chris Uncle/FilmM)

It’s also a bit of a throwback, with WAGs suddenly appearing on the cover of every newspaper and at the top of every website. Back in the noughties, the wives and girlfriends of England’s biggest football stars were almost more famous than their other halves, but in the latter half of the decade, their notoriety began to fade into the background.

Advertisement

Advertisement

And that can all be pinned down to the 2006 World Cup.

In 2006, the WAGs (a term coined by the Mail on Sunday) were permitted by then-manager Sven-Göran Eriksson not only to accompany their partners to training camp, but to the actual World Cup in Germany. Out of the 23-man squad, only 19-year-old Aaron Lennon chose not to bring a partner – meaning 22 WAGs descended on the sleepy spa town Baden-Baden.

They included David Beckham’s wife Victoria, Ashley Cole’s then-girlfriend and future wife Cheryl, Joe Cole’s then-girlfriend Carly Zucker, Frank Lampard’s then-girlfriend Elen Rivas, Peter Crouch’s then-girlfriend Abbey Clancy, and Wayne Rooney’s future bride Coleen.

Coleen joined then-boyfriend Wayne (Picture: PA Archive)

Iconic (Picture: Ross Kinnaird/Getty Images)

Cheryl accompanied then boyfriend Ashley Cole (Picture: PA Archive/PA Images)

And that summer, the WAGs gained even more press than the England team.

The WAG squad were branded ‘hooligans with Visas’ by Spanish newspaper ABC as their partying and shopping in between supporting the Lions from the stands made headlines the world over.

The ladies were pretty iconic to begin with, with Elen Rivas missing her flight after attempting to board with five pieces of hand luggage, and Victoria Beckham apparently taking 30 pairs of jeans with her to Germany.

The WAGs stayed at the Brenner’s Park Hotel, which cost £1,000 a night, and even the £26,000 they racked up on their rooms wasn’t enough for them. Alex Curran – the partner of Steven Gerrard – had to pay extra after being billed for 60 bottles of £75 pink champagne, while Elen spent an extra £2,607.

The girls made the most of their summer (Picture: Peter Macdiarmid/Getty Images)

Coleen and Alex supported their boys (Picture: ADRIAN DENNIS/AFP/Getty Images)

The ladies frequented Garibaldi’s nightclub (Picture: Chris Uncle/FilmMagic)

Cheryl and Victoria were firm friends (Picture: PA Archive)

Then came the shopping. Baden-Baden’s Hermes and Gucci branches apparently bought in £200,000 in extra stock ahead of the WAGs’ arrival, and it more than paid off, as on 19 June, the gang spent £57,000 in just one hour-long shopping trip – with Coleen herself splashing £900 in 60 minutes. Alberts sunglasses, boutiques Monica Schol and Gero Mure and jeweller Bijou Brigitte were some of the stores that benefitted from the WAGs’ loose purse strings.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Then there was their time at Garibaldi’s. One of the only nightclubs in Baden-Baden to open outside the weekend, the WAGs chose it as their favourite spot and spent most nights singing karaoke and knocking back champagne and bellinis.

It was the perfect trip – until England crashed out at the quarter-finals after losing to Portugal on penalties. Despite a lacklustre performance from the team, many blamed the WAGs for distracting their partners with their antics.

Rio Ferdinand said two years later: ‘If I’m honest, we became a bit of a circus in terms of the whole WAG situation. It seemed like there was a big show around the whole squad. It was like watching a theatre unfolding and football almost became a secondary element to the main event.

Elen Rivas tried to bring five pieces of hand luggage on her flight (Picture: PA Archive/PA Images)

Abbey Clancy was the youngest of the WAGs (Picture: Bob Thomas Sports Photography via Getty Images)

Rebekah married Jamie in 2016 (Picture: Chris Lobina/Sky via Getty Images)

‘People were worrying more about what people were wearing and where they were going out, rather than the England football team. That then transposed itself into the team. That’s said in hindsight…

‘At the time, we were caught up in the bubble ourselves. Being somewhere like Baden-Baden, walking around the town, there were paparazzi everywhere, our families were there. When you step back and look back at that, it was like a circus.’

And in 2010, manager Fabio Capello banned the WAGs from attending the entire duration of the tournament in South Africa.

Advertisement

Ahead of last year’s World Cup, Rebekah Vardy – who married Leicester hero Jamie in 2016 – distanced herself from the WAG party girl stereotype.

She told Fabulous: ‘The wives and girlfriends have a much lower profile now and that is how it should be. Our job is to be supportive.

‘I would be mortified if I was pictured leaving a bar absolutely p***ed knowing that my husband was going to play one of the biggest games of his life the next day.’

But fast forward 13 years on from Baden-Baden and the WAGs – and Rebekah – are back overshadowing their husbands in a very different way.
